metadata.description: Allocation of primary energy sources to end-use sectors, based on IEA World Energy Balances
metadata.methodology: Weighted average allocation derived from IEA energy flow data (2019-2024)
sources: IEA Energy Statistics Manual - Flow methodology
metadata.key_insight: Oil is 90% transport (high-exergy mechanical), gas is 60% low-temp heating (low-exergy), renewables are 100% electricity (high-exergy)

oil.notes: 80% road transport, aviation, shipping. 10% heating oil (residual fuel oil). 10% industrial processes.

gas.notes: 40% used in combined-cycle power plants (high efficiency). 50% residential/commercial heating (low exergy). 10% industrial process heat. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

coal.notes: Primarily used for power generation and steel/cement production (high-temperature processes). 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

nuclear.notes: 100% baseload electricity generation. 5% T&D loss applied (same as all electricity sources).

hydro.notes: 100% electricity generation (run-of-river and reservoir-based). 5% T&D loss applied (same as all electricity sources).

wind.notes: 100% electricity generation (onshore and offshore turbines). 5% T&D loss applied (same as all electricity sources).

solar.notes: 95% solar PV for electricity. 5% solar thermal for water heating. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion (same as all electricity sources).

biomass.notes: 70% traditional biomass (cooking, heating in developing countries - very low efficiency). 15% modern biofuels (transport). 10% biomass power. 5% industrial. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

geothermal.notes: 50/50 split between binary cycle power plants and direct-use heating applications. 5% T&D loss applied to electricity portion.

electricity_generation.description: All electricity has maximum exergy quality

calculation_example.description: How to calculate energy services from primary energy
steps: Step 1: Primary Energy (EJ) - from OWID data
Step 2: Useful Energy = Primary × Efficiency Factor (from efficiency_factors_corrected.json)
Step 3: Allocate to sectors using source_sector_allocation percentages
Or simplified: Energy Services = Useful Energy × Weighted_Exergy_Factor

example_coal.interpretation: Coal's useful energy of 32% reduces to 27.8% services due to 30% allocation to heat (low exergy)

example_wind.interpretation: Wind's useful energy equals services because 100% is electricity (maximum exergy)

example_gas.interpretation: Gas's useful energy of 45% reduces to 22.5% services because 50% goes to low-temp heating (exergy penalty + T&D loss)

validation_targets.global_2024_services: ~120-140 EJ (Brockway et al. 2019 baseline ~100 EJ for 2015, extrapolated to ~130 EJ for 2024)
validation_targets.clean_leverage: 1.2-1.5× (clean services share / clean useful share, per RMI 2024 efficiency advantage)
validation_targets.global_exergy_efficiency: ~22% (with stricter low-temp exergy 0.12, equal T&D losses)
validation_targets.calculation: Global services = (Σ Useful Energy × Weighted Exergy) ≈ 620 EJ primary × 0.32 useful eff × 0.65 exergy ≈ 129 EJ
validation_targets.brockway_reference: Brockway et al. 2019 - Exergy chains analysis provides EROI ratios and framework (not direct EJ totals). Baseline ~100 EJ services for 2015 extrapolated carefully.
validation_targets.td_losses_note: 5% transmission & distribution losses applied equally to all electricity sources (fossil and clean) to avoid double-counting storage losses already in efficiency factors.
